title: 109_s2235
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Tribute to Constance Baker Motley Act of 2006". Constance Baker Motley, born in 1921 in New Haven, Connecticut, was a key figure in the civil rights movement. She graduated from New York University in 1943 and later became a staff attorney at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc. Motley played a significant role in the landmark desegregation case, Brown v. Board of Education, alongside Thurgood Marshall. In 1964, Constance Baker Motley became the first African-American woman elected to the New York State Senate. In 1965, she became the first African-American woman, and the first woman, to serve as. Constance Baker Motley was the first African-American woman elected to the New York State Senate. She later became the first African-American woman to serve as president of the Borough of Manhattan. Motley continued to fight for civil rights and was appointed as a United States District Court Judge for the Southern District of New York in 1966. In 1982, she became the Chief Judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Constance Baker Motley passed away on September 28, 2005, after serving as a United States District Court Judge for nearly two decades. She is survived by her husband, son, grandchildren, brother, and sisters. Congress authorizes the posthumous presentation of a gold medal to honor Constance Baker Motley for her contributions to the United States. The design and striking of the medal will be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals may be created. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze at a price covering costs. The medal is considered a national medal and duplicates are considered numismatic items. Proceeds from sales can be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to pay for the cost of medals struck under this Act. Amounts from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited back into the Fund.
